intro: Sida galheirensis f. subtrilobata, commonly known as the three-lobed sida, is a variant of the sida plant characterized by its distinctive three-lobed leaves. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is native to tropical and subtropical regions. The plant typically grows as an annual herb, often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. Its flowers are small, yellowish, and clustered in loose inflorescences, while its seeds are encased in a fluffy pappus, aiding in wind dispersal. The species is noted for its adaptability to various environmental conditions, making it a common sight in many parts of its native range.
